question:
Of the eight students—George, Helen, Irving, Kyle, Lenore, Nina, Olivia, and Robert—in a seminar, exactly six will give individual oral reports during three consecutive days—Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday. Exactly two reports will be given each day—one in the morning and one in the afternoon—according to the following conditions: Tuesday is the only day on which George can give a report. Neither Olivia nor Robert can give an afternoon report. If Nina gives a report, then on the next day Helen and Irving must both give reports, unless Nina's report is given on Wednesday.

Which one of the following could be the schedule of the students' reports?
A) Mon. morning: Helen; Mon. afternoon: Robert Tues. morning: Olivia; Tues. afternoon: Irving Wed. morning: Lenore; Wed. afternoon: Kyle
B) Mon. morning: Irving; Mon. afternoon: Olivia Tues. morning: Helen; Tues. afternoon: Kyle Wed. morning: Nina; Wed. afternoon: Lenore
C) Mon. morning: Lenore; Mon. afternoon: Helen Tues. morning: George; Tues. afternoon: Kyle Wed. morning: Robert; Wed. afternoon: Irving
D) Mon. morning: Nina; Mon. afternoon: Helen Tues. morning: Robert; Tues. afternoon: Irving Wed. morning: Olivia; Wed. afternoon: Lenore
E) Mon. morning: Olivia; Mon. afternoon: Nina Tues. morning: Irving; Tues. afternoon: Helen Wed. morning: Kyle; Wed. afternoon: George
chain_of_thought: George can only speak on Tuesday, and neither Olivia nor Robert can give an afternoon report. Option A fails because Olivia gives an afternoon report. Option B fails because George cannot give a report on Monday and Robert cannot give an afternoon report. Option C fails because George gives a report on Tuesday. Option D fails because Robert gives a report on Monday and Olivia gives a report on Wednesday. Option E does not violate any conditions and satisfies the given conditions, so it could be the schedule of the students' reports.
full_output:
<think>George can only speak on Tuesday, and neither Olivia nor Robert can give an afternoon report. Option A fails because Olivia gives an afternoon report. Option B fails because George cannot give a report on Monday and Robert cannot give an afternoon report. Option C fails because George gives a report on Tuesday. Option D fails because Robert gives a report on Monday and Olivia gives a report on Wednesday. Option E does not violate any conditions and satisfies the given conditions, so it could be the schedule of the students' reports.</think>
<ans>E</ans>
hint_sentence: When a specific day is the only day on which a particular student can give a report, this condition should be taken into account before considering any other possibilities. Consider each student's restrictions individually, and look for combinations that satisfy all the given conditions.

question:
The organizer of a reading club will select at least five and at most six works from a group of nine works. The group consists of three French novels, three Russian novels, two French plays, and one Russian play. The organizer's selection of works must conform to the following requirements: No more than four French works are selected. At least three but no more than four novels are selected. At least as many French novels as Russian novels are selected. If both French plays are selected, then the Russian play is not selected.

Which one of the following could be the organizer's selection of works?
A) one French novel, two Russian novels, one French play, one Russian play
B) two French novels, one Russian novel, two French plays, one Russian play
C) two French novels, two Russian novels, two French plays
D) three French novels, one Russian novel, two French plays
E) three French novels, two Russian novels, one Russian play
chain_of_thought: Since no more than four French works are selected, and at least three but no more than four novels are selected, we must choose between options D and E. To determine which is valid, we must consider the other requirements. In D, we have three French novels, one Russian novel, and two French plays, so we have at least as many French novels as Russian novels. However, if both French plays are selected, then the Russian play is not selected, which is satisfied in D. In E, we have three French novels, two Russian novels, and one Russian play, so we have at least as many French novels as Russian novels. However, since we have more than four French works, option E is invalid. Therefore, the only valid option is D.
full_output:
<think>Since no more than four French works are selected, and at least three but no more than four novels are selected, we must choose between options D and E. To determine which is valid, we must consider the other requirements. In D, we have three French novels, one Russian novel, and two French plays, so we have at least as many French novels as Russian novels. However, if both French plays are selected, then the Russian play is not selected, which is satisfied in D. In E, we have three French novels, two Russian novels, and one Russian play, so we have at least as many French novels as Russian novels. However, since we have more than four French works, option E is invalid. Therefore, the only valid option is D.</think>
<ans>D</ans>
hint_sentence: When considering the requirements, remember that "at least as many French novels as Russian novels are selected" doesn't necessarily mean you must select a French novel. It can still be satisfied when both counts are zero.

If Landon is assigned to an ambassadorship, it is to Zambia.

A) Venezuela: Jaramillo Yemen: Ong Zambia: Novetzke
B) Venezuela: Kayne Yemen: Jaramillo Zambia: Landon

D) Venezuela: Novetzke Yemen: Jaramillo Zambia: Kayne
E) Venezuela: Ong Yemen: Kayne Zambia: Landon

This leaves only one valid option, but that is not C. C failed because both Kayne and Novetzke were assigned. The only option left is the option that is the opposite of C, which is the option that has Novetzke assigned to Venezuela and Jaramillo assigned to Yemen, and Landon assigned to Zambia, which is option D. D is valid because it does not violate any of the conditions, and the other options are invalid because they violate one or more of the conditions.

Each sales representative works in exactly one of the sales zones, in accordance with the following conditions: Either Parra or Tiao (but not both) works in Zone 1. Either Tiao or Udall (but not both) works in Zone 2. Parra and Quinn work in the same sales zone as each other. Stuckey and Udall work in the same sales zone as each other. There are more of the sales representatives working in Zone 3 than in Zone 2.

Which one of the following could be a complete and accurate list of the sales representatives working in Zone 3?
A) Kim, Mahr
B) Kim, Tiao
C) Parra, Quinn
D) Stuckey, Tiao, Udall
E) Parra, Quinn, Stuckey, Udall
chain_of_thought: Since Parra and Quinn work in the same sales zone as each other, and Stuckey and Udall work in the same sales zone as each other, these pairs must be in Zone 3. Either Parra or Tiao works in Zone 1, so Tiao cannot be in Zone 3. Either Tiao or Udall works in Zone 2, so Udall cannot be in Zone 3. Given that there are more representatives in Zone 3 than in Zone 2, and the only representatives left are Kim, Mahr, Parra, Quinn, Stuckey, and Tiao, the only option that includes more representatives than Zone 2 is E, which has four representatives in Zone 3.
full_output:
<think>Since Parra and Quinn work in the same sales zone as each other, and Stuckey and Udall work in the same sales zone as each other, these pairs must be in Zone 3. Either Parra or Tiao works in Zone 1, so Tiao cannot be in Zone 3. Either Tiao or Udall works in Zone 2, so Udall cannot be in Zone 3. Given that there are more representatives in Zone 3 than in Zone 2, and the only representatives left are Kim, Mahr, Parra, Quinn, Stuckey, and Tiao, the only option that includes more representatives than Zone 2 is E, which has four representatives in Zone 3.</think>
<ans>E</ans>
hint_sentence: The presence or absence of a sales representative in a particular zone can have a ripple effect on the others, due to the conditions that specify which representatives work together. Consider the implications of each condition on the possible distribution of representatives across the zones. Be cautious not to make assumptions about which representatives are in a particular zone without considering all the given conditions.

question:
During a recital, two pianists—Wayne and Zara—will perform solos. There will be five solos altogether, performed one immediately after another. Each solo will be either a modern piece or a traditional piece. The choice of pianist and type of piece for the solos must conform to the following conditions: The third solo is a traditional piece. Exactly two of the traditional pieces are performed consecutively. In the fourth solo, either Wayne performs a traditional piece or Zara performs a modern piece. The pianist who performs the second solo does not perform the fifth solo. No traditional piece is performed until Wayne performs at least one modem piece.

Which one of the following could be all of the solos that are traditional pieces?
A) the first, third, and fourth
B) the second, third, and fourth
C) the third and fourth
D) the third and fifth
E) the fourth and fifth
chain_of_thought: Since no traditional piece is performed until Wayne performs at least one modern piece, the first two solos must be modern. The third solo is traditional, and since exactly two traditional pieces are performed consecutively, the fourth and fifth solos must also be traditional. The fourth solo has the condition that either Wayne performs a traditional piece or Zara performs a modern piece, but since the fourth and fifth solos are both traditional, this condition is satisfied. The pianist who performs the second solo does not perform the fifth solo, and since the second and fifth solos are modern and traditional respectively, this condition is also satisfied. Therefore, the only option that could be all of the solos that are traditional pieces is D, the third and fifth.
full_output:
<think>Since no traditional piece is performed until Wayne performs at least one modern piece, the first two solos must be modern. The third solo is traditional, and since exactly two traditional pieces are performed consecutively, the fourth and fifth solos must also be traditional. The fourth solo has the condition that either Wayne performs a traditional piece or Zara performs a modern piece, but since the fourth and fifth solos are both traditional, this condition is satisfied. The pianist who performs the second solo does not perform the fifth solo, and since the second and fifth solos are modern and traditional respectively, this condition is also satisfied. Therefore, the only option that could be all of the solos that are traditional pieces is D, the third and fifth.</think>
<ans>D</ans>
hint_sentence: The condition "no traditional piece is performed until Wayne performs at least one modern piece" doesn't mean Wayne has to perform a modern piece after the first traditional piece; it just means he has to perform at least one modern piece before the first traditional piece.

question:
Exactly five witnesses—Franco, Garcia, Hong, Iturbe, and Jackson—are to be scheduled to testify at a hearing that is to take exactly three days of one week—Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday. Each witness testifies on exactly one day of the hearing. The schedule must meet the following conditions: Franco does not testify on the same day that Garcia testifies. Iturbe testifies on Wednesday. Exactly two witnesses testify on Tuesday. Hong does not testify on Monday. At least one witness testifies on Monday.

Which one of the following is an acceptable schedule of witnesses?
A) Monday: Franco Tuesday: Hong and Iturbe Wednesday: Garcia and Jackson
B) Monday: Franco and Hong Tuesday: Iturbe and Jackson Wednesday: Garcia
C) Monday: Garcia Tuesday: Franco and Iturbe Wednesday: Hong and Jackson
D) Monday: Garcia and Jackson Tuesday: Franco and Hong Wednesday: Iturbe
E) Monday: Garcia and Jackson Tuesday: Hong Wednesday: Franco and Iturbe
chain_of_thought: Iturbe is on Wednesday, and exactly two witnesses are on Tuesday. This means Hong and Iturbe are on Tuesday, as Garcia and Franco cannot be on the same day. Garcia and Franco must be on Monday and Wednesday, and the only option that satisfies this condition is B, as Garcia is on Monday, Franco is on Wednesday, and Hong and Iturbe are on Tuesday.
full_output:
<think>Iturbe is on Wednesday, and exactly two witnesses are on Tuesday. This means Hong and Iturbe are on Tuesday, as Garcia and Franco cannot be on the same day. Garcia and Franco must be on Monday and Wednesday, and the only option that satisfies this condition is B, as Garcia is on Monday, Franco is on Wednesday, and Hong and Iturbe are on Tuesday.</think>
<ans>B</ans>
hint_sentence: Given that exactly two witnesses must testify on Tuesday, consider the remaining two days (Monday and Wednesday) as a pair. Try to assign the witnesses to Monday and Wednesday first, and then fill in Tuesday.

This means that the only possible slot 5 is occupied by Zircon, so Zircon is in slot 5. Therefore, the only option that cannot be in slot 5 is Uneasy, since Yardsign is in slot 5 in all valid cases.

E) screen 1: western at 7 P.M., mystery at 9 P.M. screen 2: sci-fi film at 7 P.M., romance at 9 P.M. screen 3: horror film at 8 P.M.
chain_of_thought: The western must start before the horror film. The romance cannot be on screen 2, and the sci-fi film cannot be on screen 3. The horror and mystery films are on different screens.
